text:
Situation A. Shipping Containers' Details

A filled identical shipping containers are stacked on a ship to form a rectangular prism, called a load. The load is built up in layers.
1. How could you calculate the total number of containers in each load?

You can calculate how many containers in one layer, such as the base. Then, you can multiply the number of containers in each layer by the number of layers. In Load 3 of the diagram, there are 5 layers (5 containers in the height) and the total number of containers is (4 x 5) x 5 = 100.

2. Suppose a shipâ€™s load has

  • 10 containers in each row from left to right;
  • 15 containers in each row from front to back; and
  • 8 layers of containers.

How may containers are in the whole load?
1200 containers. In each layer, there are 10 x 15 = 150 containers. Since there are 8 layers, the total number of containers is 150 x 8 = 1200.
3. How is finding the number of containers in each load like finding the volume of a rectangular prism?

For each one you are finding the number of cubic units that it takes to fill it up a load. Each one can be found by finding the number of containers in one layer and then multiplying that by the number of layers. Each one can be computed using the formula V = l x w x h or V = Bh.

Situation B. Packaging Basketballs

Basketballs are spheres, but they are often packaged in boxes in the shape of cubes.
1. How many of these boxes would fit into a shipping container that is 6 feet long by 5 feet wide by 4 feet high? Describe the arrangement of the boxes.

120.

The bottom layer will have 30 boxes in 6 rows of 5 (or 5 rows of 6), and there are 4 identical layers.

2. What are the dimensions of other rectangular containers that would hold the same number of basketball boxes? Describe the arrangement of the boxes in each case. Which containers make the most sense? The least sense?

Answers will vary. Possible answers:

  • 120 = 2 x 3 x 20 (2 rows of 3 and 20 layers; 2 rows of 20 and 3 layers; 3 rows of 20 and 2 layers)
  • 120 = 3 x 4 x 10 (3 rows of 4 and 10 layers; 4 rows of 10 and 3 layers; 10 rows of 3 and 4 layers)
  • 120 = 3 x 5 x 8 (3 rows of 5 and 8 layers; 5 rows of 8 and 3 layers; 8 rows of 3 and 5 layers)
  • 120 = 2 x 5 x 12 (2 rows of 5 and 12 layers; 5 rows of 12 and 2 layers; 12 rows of 2 and 5 layers)
  • 2 x 3 x 20; 20 as a height does not make much sense because it will be too tall compared to its base.
  • 4(height) x 5(width) x 6(length) makes sense the most because the containers will be easy to be stacked.
3. Suppose your classroom is a shipping container that is a rectangular prism. How many of these basketball boxes would fit in your classroom? Describe the arrangement of the boxes.

Answers will vary depending on the dimensions of the room. You can measure the length, width, and height of the room and get the number of boxes in each dimension. If the measurements are not whole numbers, then the answer is not so clear, but, in all likelihood, students will calculate the number by rounding each dimension down to a whole number.
4. How much cardboard is needed to make a box for one basketball?

6 ft2

6 square feet because there are 6 faces in a box and each face is 1 ft x 1 ft = 1 square foot.

Also, the amount of cardboard for all the boxes is 6 x 120 = 720 square feet because there are 120 boxes in one container.
